title: Real-world fractions
prompt:
Javier is making a cake for a party. The recipe calls for 2 3 4 cups of flour,
but he wants to triple the recipe. He guessed and put in 7 cups of flour.
How much more flour should he have used?
(Type in your answer as a decimal.)
hint: The first step in working with mixed numbers is to convert them to improper fractions.
feedback:
Change mixed numbers to improper fractions by multiplying the whole-number part by the denominator and adding the numerator. This is the new numerator. 
<math>
<mrow>
 <mfrac linethickness="1">
  <mrow>
   <mn>2</mn>
   <mo>⋅</mo>
   <mn>4</mn>
   <mo>+</mo>
   <mn>3</mn>
  </mrow>
  <mn>4</mn>
 </mfrac>
 <mo>=</mo>
 <mfrac linethickness="1">
  <mn>11</mn>
  <mn>4</mn>
 </mfrac>
</mrow>
</math>. Triple means multiply by 3, which gives  
<math>
<mrow>
 <mfrac linethickness="1">
  <mn>33</mn>
  <mn>4</mn>
 </mfrac>
</mrow>
</math>. Convert 7 to a fraction with 4 in the denominator: <math>
<mrow>
 <mfrac linethickness="1">
  <mn>28</mn>
  <mn>4</mn>
 </mfrac>
</mrow>
</math>
. The difference is 
<math>
<mrow>
 <mfrac linethickness="1">
  <mn>5</mn>
  <mn>4</mn>
 </mfrac>
</mrow>
</math>
or 
<math>
<mrow>
 <mn>1</mn>
 <mfrac linethickness="1">
  <mn>1</mn>
  <mn>4</mn>
 </mfrac>
</mrow>
</math>.
